Good day loyal readers, I hope you're all enjoying the beautiful weather we're having today.

I'm not really sure what to blog about, so i'll just go with it. This should be a quick one. Last Sunday I got the flu and boy, what a ride it has been. I wound up in an ambulance and took a trip to the emergency room last Monday night. I had a fever of 101.5 and I couldn't see straight or walk properly. I knew it was the flu, and after a few tests, it was determined to be nothing beyond that. It was better to be safe than sorry, however. There was some concern among people I know that it could be H1N1, but thankfully it wasn't. I've lost about 15 pounds since I've had the flu, and I'm almost fully recovered. I can't recall ever having been that sick in my entire life. My mom has been taking great care of me, as have a few of my friends at my place.

This isn't the first time I've had the flu, but there was something in this flu bug that has had a profound impact on my life. I hate to use the term "life changing" as I wasn't dying or anything (though I certainly felt like I was at times) but ever since I got this virus, a lot of things have been put into perspective for me. For one, I can't even stand the smell of marijuana smoke anymore, and I just shudder anytime I see pot-related paraphanalia. I know it sounds like the same old thing, but I am finished smoking weed for good. No more "well, just one last time with my buddies" or anything like that. Even when I chill with my boys from up north again, I won't touch the stuff. If you can't respect that, don't expect to see me around. I know it's not the reason I got sick, but I have wanted to quit for some time and whatever is in this flu bug gave me the kick in the ass I needed to give it up.

If my recovery continues to progress at it's current rate, I should be out and about all week, finally getting my life in gear. Another thing that I dawned upon was that I no longer want to prove people wrong in life. That's not fair to those that have always believed in me. My purpose in life is to reward the faith of the people who have stuck with me through thick and thin throughout the years; to show them that they stuck with me for a reason. I will still use some of that fuel from the doubters to push myself, but the main purpose being to reward the believers. It's the people like Danielle, Nick (I know we don't speak now but trust me, he's seen it all with me), Jay, Rashad, Joe, Rachel, Frank...ect. that I want to reward. I want to better myself so that I may help others better themselves. We all have a major turning point in our lives, and I believe this is one of them. Rome wasn't built in a day, but I'm sure it was one hell of a ride.

I hate to cut this short, but my laptop battery is getting pretty low, and I feel like going to sit in the hot tub at the Y for a bit, so i'll do just that. Enjoy the rest of your day folks!

-Paul C.

Good day everyone, I hope all is well and that you're all enjoying this beautiful weather we're having. Even in Timmins it's been really warm and the snow is melting rapidly, according to my dad. Can't Timmins have just ONE icy cold, snow-filled winter when I'm not there? I'm talking 4 feet of snow and temperatures hovering around -40 on a daily basis. Basically, the real-life version of Hell freezing over, lol! Just once is all I ask. I may actually sell my soul to make this happen. Stay tuned.

A few days ago, I randomly ran into one of my buddies from college, Greg. It was unbelievable. I was thrilled. I went downstairs in the lobby at my place to see my buddy Dan, and then Greg came walking in and we were both like "Whoa, what's up?" He said he wants to play basketball with me again soon and I said I'm looking forward to it. If you'll recall, Greg was this 6'5 guy on my intramural basketball team who dunks like I breathe. No way we make the finals without him.

Greg is one of the guys I played with that knows just how good a player I can be, and he witnessed me at my best first hand. Maybe my shooting was off because of my broken wrist, but I more than made up for it on defense. Of all the guys I've played basketball with up north, Jay is probably the only guy who would fit in seamlessly on my college intramural team. No offense to the northern ballers, as I have great respect for them (well, moreso Timmins High), but the level of competition down here, even in intramurals, is way better than any runs you can find up north.

I'm still on the job hunt. I had an interview on Friday at a place called Global Air Care, which is essentially a company that manufactures and distributes home air filtration systems. The interview went well and I was told to call them back between 4:30pm-5pm that evening to find out if I had been hired. From 4:30pm to 7pm, I called every 5 minutes and the line was busy. Quite a company eh? In retrospect, it's kind of amusing. The head of the company had a pair of 19th century firearms framed in his office. Now THAT is a boss i'd like to work for.

If you haven't already seen the movie called "The Cove" I highly recommend either downloading it, renting it or purchasing it. Whether marines mammals interest you or not, it's a must watch for all animal lovers and basically, anyone with a soul.

I thought this would be a longer blog, but I'm getting stir crazy and feel like going out again. It's too nice to just be cooped up inside all day. Granted, I've been doing some reading (Bill Simmons "Book of Basketball") but I can continue with that later on tonight.

Enjoy the rest of your day folks!

-Paul C.

Good afternoon everyone, I hope your day has gotten off to a fantastic start. Mine sure has.

The first thing I did today was get my rent paid, as it's the smart thing to do. My mom's birthday is tomorrow so I am going to get her something nice and make sure she has an awesome day. Later on today, i'll be getting a haircut. It's long overdue, to say the least. I should donate my hair to a cancer organization that makes wigs for cancer patients. It's thick enough and would probably make two wigs. Well actually, i'd like to donate part of my hair to Raiders owner Al Davis. Come on man, get rid of the toupé already!

I've been watching the Olympics and it's just been awesome. The Canada-USA hockey game was just insane. We dominated them but the goals Canada gave up were just sloppy plays by some of team Canada's elder statesmen. Luckily we bounced back against the Swedes, so we get to play Russia. This should be a fun match up. And yes, I will be not-so-secretly rooting for Alex Ovechkin. I'm sorry, but if Jason effing Whitehead can be a fan of Ovie, then I have every right to cheer for him (and him alone) in a game against team Canada. Remember, Jay is the guy who hates hockey more than anything. I'm pretty sure hockey is on his Mount Rushmore of sports hatred, along with the following 3 people: Carmelo Anthony, Bill Laimbeer, and Rajon Rondo. So there.

The weather here in Hamilton has been great. There was a bit of a snowstorm (by their standards) on Monday. They actually closed the library early due to inclement weather. Of course, those same people made the brilliant decision to turn on the fans full blast here in the food court when I sat down to browse the web on my laptop. This may be a novel concept to some people, but if you're closing the library due to inclement weather, why would you then proceed to make the people inside the building freeze their asses off? This isn't "The Day After Tomorrow." I half-expected to walk outside and see half the city buried in snow, with Dennis Quaid lurching towards the door to try and rescue the others trapped inside the mall.

The NBA trading deadline passed last week and Amare Stoudemire is still a Phoenix Sun. That is somewhat surprising. I hate to say it, but Steve Kerr is among the worst GM's in the NBA. Granted, he's being handcuffed by Robert "Penny Pincher" Sarver, but they had to have known that Amare is going to bolt this summer. They won't get anything in return for him, unless the Knicks take pity on the Suns and offer them Al Harrington in a sign and trade. Way to waste Steve Nash's career. Kerr, you're a great color commentator. It's your destiny to be an all-time great NBA color commentator. I think even Suns fans would agree with me here. Actually, they probably have about 27 different chapters of "Fire Sarver" in the Phoenix and Glendale area. Suns fans, make your choice.

I have more to type about but I'm starting to get hungry. Ugh, the lady who just sat down next to me has the worst smelling french fries ever. It's as if she literally fried them in piss and vinegar. I'm no longer hungry anymore.

Have an awesome day folks.

regards,
Paul C.

Welcome back to my blog, loyal readers (the 3 of you that actually read this blog, haha). It's been awhile since my last blog entry, due to technical issues with my laptop. I'm happy to announce that my laptop is as good as new and I will be posting blogs on a regular basis once again.

I'm not sure where to start, seeing as how it's been so long. I moved here to Hamilton on December 30th, which I felt was a much needed change of scenery for me. Waterloo is probably the most serene city I've ever lived in and i'll likely move there again someday. The house I lived in was nice, and at least one of my roommates was cool.

The best way I can describe Matt (the roommate I couldn't stand) is that he is the step-father I never had. I'm sure he meant well at times, but I was going through a really tough time and I made it clear from the beginning that I needed my space and that any issues you had were to be explained to me in a civilized manner.

Even before I moved in, I explained to Matt that I was extremely depressed (having lost Fluke on November 5th, which, based on what I went through, was akin to someone with a cast on their leg doing attempting to do yoga or pilates). What did Matt do? Nit-picked the shit out of everything I did, from my cooking ability to my job searching habits. Look, anyone who has experienced depression knows that you barely eat, let alone cook an elaborate meal. If you choose to eat when you're depressed, you just want the food to taste half decent, that's it.

The best part of everything that he was doing was the fact that he was a blatant hypocrite the entire time. Look for a job? I was doing that, but because he never saw me doing it, he criticized me. He was on welfare and all day he would sit and game in his room. Oh, and the creme de la creme: he had a wife and kids who lived with her and her parents in another city, while he was living where I did gaming and blazing all the time. Granted, I did my fair share of blazing when I lived there, but still, it was rather comical.

One of the best nights I had in Waterloo was the night when Harmony came to visit. We'd known each other for over 3 years via the Irishman, but we had yet to meet. I walked my dog Theo to meet her downtown, then we walked back to my place. On the walk back, we witnessed a car accident, which was pretty bad ass if you ask me. A van turned into a lane without signaling and was blindsided by a car. Of course, being the attention-seeking showman that I am, and always looking to put a funny spin on things, I yelled out "CHOO LOSE! Enjoy the jacked insurance rates, hahaha!" much to Harmony's chagrin. Okay, she laughed a little. Meh, a stupid driving decision deserves an equally stupid response from some passersby.

After we got back to my place, I noticed my roommates were blazing so I decided to join them while we all chilled in the living room. Harmony didn't mind my getting baked despite her presence, which was nice. I told her beforehand that I'm perfectly fine when I'm high (hahahahahahahaha!!!!!!) so to prove a point, I got extremely baked and somehow managed to avoid saying anything dumb or weird. My subconscious knew better, I suppose. Harmony adored the two cats who were living at the house, Reckless and Lean. She was fawning over Lean in particular, as she is a tiny kitten. She wanted to steal Lean and I unsuccessfully attempted to get her to go through with it, haha! After a few hours of chilling and gaming, I walked her to the bus stop and waited until her bus came.

I spent New Year's in Toronto, which was a first for me. Even after 3 years, it still feels weird to go back to the city where I got engaged for the first time. I do think about Marie when I'm there, to be honest with you. I rode the subway for the first time since I dated her, and I was actually surprised it didn't upset me, despite the time that has lapsed. Wherever Marie is, I hope she's doing fantastic. She deserves it.

I spent that evening with my mom and a bunch of her friends, and a few of their kids. Thankfully, Chris (Debbie's son) is my age, so I had someone to just chill with for most of the night. I took a lot of goofy and funny pictures that night, which I posted on facebook. We wound up watching the ball drop in Nathan Phillips Square. It was one of the most amazing experiences of my life. It was a beautiful night, the women were equally gorgeous, and I met some people who I added to facebook. The only way the night could have been better would have been if I had gotten a New Year's kiss (which has still eluded me after 24 years) and had Papa Roach been the band playing live that night, as opposed to some no-name rock group that literally no one had heard of. It was really funny when the host (some MTV guy) yelled out to the crowd asking if they had heard of the band (whose name has slipped my mind) and the crowd went silent. He attempted this twice. After the second attempt, the crowd just lost it and everyone had a good laugh.

The first thing I yelled out when the new year arrived was "I LOVE YOU FLUKEY!" in honor of my dog. A few people (somehow) heard me and thought it was cute. That's going to be the first phrase I utter every new year until the day I die. What, like you expected anything else? It's Fluke, come on!

A few weeks ago, I did one of the dumbest things of my life and took two Oxycontin's while I was partying at a friends place. I almost died that night, which was one of the scariest things I've ever experienced in my life. I will always be convinced that Fluke was watching over me that night, as there is no way I should have survived, when you factor in I took half a morphine pill and two other muscle relaxants in addition to taking the Oxy's. I hadn't realized taking two Oxy's could kill you until someone conveniently told me after I had popped the second pill. Regardless, it was mistake I will never make again. I have healthier appreciation for life and believe that Fluke saved my life because he wants to see me succeed in life, which I will.

I celebrated my 24th birthday on February 9th, as many of you know. It was my first birthday without Fluke since I turned 12. I made the best of it and partied with a few of my friends. Fluke was at the forefront of my thoughts the entire night, however, and I had a really fun time that night.

That's my blog entry for today. I hope you all enjoyed reading it and I hope you all have a fantastic day.

regards,
The Truth

Wow, where do I begin? Seeing at how I'm at Starbucks, I suppose i'll keep this blog short, with a much more detailed one to come shortly.

I'm now living in Waterloo, and I'm a basketball coach in the Waterloo Youth Basketball Association. I coach in the Juvenile division, and my team consists of 16 and 17-year old boys. They all know how to play, and it's great. I'm running my first practice tonight at 8pm, which is at Ressurection High School. My team lacks size, but every single one of my players can shoot the ball, handle it, and they're surprisingly proficient at grabbing rebounds.

I'll go into more detail in my next blog, as I'm pretty busy today. My next game is Thursday night at 6pm at Ressurection. Anyone of my friends in the Waterloo area is free to attend the game.

Have a great day everyone.

-coach Paul C.

Hey folks, thanks for once again reading my blog. I have a few things I am going to cover in this one, so let's get on with it.

Yeah, I am attention seeker. Nobody in Timmins should be surprised by this. When you hang out with people maybe once a week (if you're lucky) you tend to want attention. It's human nature. What do you expect me to do? Just sit here on my laptop all day and night and just be okay with being alone? Well I can't do that. I'm a very social person, and I love being around good people. College changed that for me. When I went, I was lucky to have one night a week to just have some alone time. At times, I had to ignore my friends just so I could be alone and have a "me night." I was actually around people who didn't always look for something to fault me for.

Up here in Timmins, I notice that a lot. Be it a high school thing or somebody hearing something about me, I just find that people spend more time trying to find ways NOT to like me rather than actually getting to know who I am. My own friends are guilty of that. My proof lies in the fact that back in high school, I was really messed up. Yet I still had plans with friends pretty much every week-end. I've matured since then, and yet now, I've been reduced to "day time hang out if I can't find someone else to chill with." Like what the fuck?

My friends up here almost seem disappointed that I've gotten better. I guess they miss being able to rag on me for my inability to get a girl or whatever. I don't know what more you people want from me. I know I'm not perfect, so understand that.

There is a reason why people constantly wanted to be around me in college. I didn't change completely when I went away for school, I just was able to open up more and people were receptive to it. Of course I'm going to want attention when you go from THAT to THIS. And yet you're surprised by all this? Well you shouldn't be. It shouldn't be odd that I want to hang out with my friends that I had back in high school (Jay, Rachel...ect.). I really don't get it. Rachel and I chilled a few times a week from October through December. She would actually call me to go hang out. Now, I would be shocked if I heard from her.

Jay is the same way. I'm shocked when he asks me to hang out. Usually, it's me saying something like "Yo, I got weed, wanna chill?" Well of course he'll want to. Free weed, he won't say no to that. It's pathetic yet I do it because it's either that or I'm home doing fuck all.

I just find it pretty fucking ridiculous when people up here are shocked that I want to hang out with them or something. I'm not a damn serial killer or rapist or anything. Yet people look at me that way for some reason. Pardon me for dressing nice and being upbeat and wanting to chill and have fun. I'm human and I'm very social, so it should come as no surprise.

Look, I know I talk a lot up here. I've never felt fully accepted by my friends so that constant chatter is my way of trying to prove myself. To show that I AM as a good friend as anyone else you know. I was like that in Windsor for about a month, until I finally realized that my friends there accepted me and genuinely wanted to be around me. It wasn't because I had weed or because I knew a guy who could get weed. No, it was because they liked who I was and what I was about.

Yeah, people up here may say something like "They didn't know him in high school" or "They don't know him like we do." Well, I graduated high school 3 years ago. I've changed a lot since then. What people up here knew about me, they knew who I WAS, not who I AM.

It's easy to judge someone when you don't take the time to get to know them, and instead go off what other people say or how they look. I don't expect to have plans every single day, or for people to always call me 24/7 wanting to hang out. My life has never been normal, which you all know. But having an actual social life brings a sense of normalcy to my life that I really enjoy. Like it or not, your life is shaped by the people around you. So obviously I was much happier and upbeat in Windsor (where I went to college) because I was accepted and people wanted to be around me. It's positive vibes. When people want to be around you, naturally, it makes you feel good because you know people care.

I start my new job on Monday, and for once, I want to meet some new friends at work. Hopefully, i'll have some old friends (such as Rachel) want to hang out with me again and finally accept that I'm not the same person I was in high school; that I'm much better than I was. I don't expect everyone to like me, but getting an active social life again would be great.

Really, I'm hoping that my friends from here start treating me like an actual friend instead of just an obligation or a weed hook up. It shouldn't surprise you (this entire blog) yet some people will be surprised by it. The people who understand this blog will either be intelligent and unbiased, or people who actually ARE my friend and treat me as such.

I know that I'm not perfect company. Everyone has flaws. But are mine so bad that I don't deserve to have a regular social life?* Of course not. I want to get better as a person, and I will. It doesn't happen overnight.

Women up here are pretty ridiculous. Any time I even so much as glance at one, they give me the evil eye. Ladies, understand this: not every guy who checks you out wants to fuck you. The sooner you understand that, the better off you'll be. Do you ever think that hey, a guy is checking you out because he thinks you're cute? Or because he's a naturally friendly person? And I don't overdo it. It's usually just a quick glance and a smile that maybe last 2 seconds, tops. And yet there's something wrong with that? Wow.

Thanks for reading and have a great night.

-Paul

* = if you answered yes to that question, then you shouldn't have bothered reading this.

Good morning people. I hope you're enjoying the nice snow fall (here in Timmins, at least). It's spring, there should be no more snow! Oh well, hopefully it gets nicer later on today.

Yesterday was a pretty awesome day. I went into my new work place (called On-Line Support) and filled out some paperwork, which took about 5 minutes. I found out that i'll be starting on Monday, and that Rachel will be in my training class, which is cool. We haven't hung out in awhile, so I hope we actually get along in class. I guess that's her call.

Afterwards, I went to Jay's and we chilled for the evening. We watched the Bulls-Celtics, and what a game that was. It went to triple overtime. The series is tied at 3-3. Of those 6 games, 4 have gone into overtime, which is an NBA record for ANY round in the play offs.

I was rooting for the Boston Celtics in this series, but after Rajon Rondo's cheap shot on Brad Miller in Game 5 (which he should have been suspended for, but wasn't, for whatever reason) I switched sides. The game was as intense and physical as Whitehead and I expected it to be. Kirk Hinrich, wow! He was ready to fight Rajon Rondo after Rondo grabbed him and threw him into the scorer's table. Of course, Rondo wasn't ejected. What more do the officials want before they'll finally eject Rondo from a game? It just seems fishy to me.

I came away thoroughly impressed with Bulls center Joakim Noah, a guy I love to hate. He played really well and had a sick fast break dunk in which Paul Pierce fouled him (his 6th and final foul of the game).

Kirk Hinrich and Brad Miller (of the Bulls) are two players I gained a TON of respect for after last night's game. I had always liked Hinrich, and was so-so on Brad Miller. I was just blown away at the way Hinrich played. Plus his near-fight with Rondo was great. He was ready to knock him out after Rondo tossed him into the scorers table. Brad Miller just played great. You talk about redemption, Miller just took it to the Celtics. His clutch 3-pointer late in the 4th quarter was fantastic.

The Houston Rockets finally made it out of the first round for the first time since 1997. Of course, it was without the injured Tracy McGrady, who can finally tell people he made it to the second round for the first time in his career. I still believe that McGrady should be given a Ewing Theory award. It's his destiny to win one, and this series locked up that award for him.

Well, I am going to enjoy this day. I have a few things planned, so I'm looking forward to having a great day. You people do the same.

Take care everyone.

-Paul

I have returned! Yes, it's been almost 3 months since my last blog entry, and for that, I apologize. I appreciate the comments on my last blog, even though I have no idea who wrote them. I'm pretty sure the first one was from Nick, but the rest, I'm not sure. Whoever it was, I really appreciate it.

One of the reasons I haven't posted in awhile is because I forgot my password. I tried the "forgot password" tool, which wasn't of much use to me, as this blog is registered under an old e-mail address of mine. Seeing as how I change my e-mail address more often than I talk about basketball, well, I guess you can see why the mishap occurred.

I guess i'll mention the women, as I always tend to do in my blogs. I re-read my previous entry a few minutes ago and I feel bad about it. It's pretty ridiculous to group every woman up here with a few bad apples. Well, few is an understatement, but you get my point. blah blah blah, whatever.

The NBA Play Offs are in full swing, and I couldn't be happier. My San Antonio Spurs trail the Dallas Mavericks 2-1 in their first round match up. Game 4 is tonight in Dallas. San Antonio is coming off an embarrassing 21 point loss in Game 3. Am I worried? Nope. The Mavs will choke (again) and the Spurs don't lose in the first round. Easy enough, I suppose.

Next month is when I finally go to Ottawa to visit Nick. I'll be going for about a week, so it should be fun. I guess i'll just add this sentence so that this paragraph actually looks like a paragraph.

I'm a little over a month away from going to see Dr. Hardy about my knees. June 2nd is basically what I've referred to as "D-Day." Decision day. I'll find out whether I need surgery, medication, or physio to help get my knees back to 100%, if it's even possible. I want to be able to get back out there and play basketball at full strength. I haven't played since November, which is driving me nuts. I'm determined to get into great shape this summer and increase my vert, speed, and quickness. Why? Because I love the game of basketball.

I've recently become hooked on the new craze that is Twitter. It's pretty neat and it's nice to see athletes and celebrities get PROPERLY quoted, for once.

That's all I feel like saying for now. I'll churn out blogs more frequently from now on, however.

Thanks for reading and have a great day.

-Paul

Yes, it is about time that I typed a new blog. Seeing as how I plan on actually keeping this blog posted, it's officially my first blog of 2009.

I really won't say too much about 2008, because it's not a year worth mentioning. As a matter of fact, i'd like to forget the past 2 years and all of last month. For one, I was proven right (many times) in my generalization of Timmins girls. I won't get too much into it, but let's just say "girls" is the right term to use for females up here. I know I have flaws, as does everybody, but they really blew my mind, and not in a good way. Even a certain female from southern Ontario did her best Timmins girl impersonation, which was interesting. But I guess now I can understand why her and I didn't speak for almost 2 years.

I'm not saying I'm the best guy out there or whatever. I do have flaws, and I recognize them. But are they so bad that I don't deserve a nice girl? Of course not. Pardon me for not being perfect.

I went to my buddy Brad's for the Super Bowl on Sunday.  The game was fantastic to watch. It was down to the wire and I had a blast that night.

There is a good possibility that I'm getting an authentic Kobe Bryant Lakers jersey for $80. Nick runs a business that sells authentic sports jerseys at great prices (about 1/3 of the retail cost). He and his girlfriend run it. If you want anything in particular, message me on MSN or facebook and i'll try to get in contact with him (he doesn't want to talk to me and I don't know if he ever will again).

Have a splendid day everyone.

-Paulus

Today has been pretty fun. I am indeed in the holiday spirit. I finally got an appointment with an orthopedic surgeon regarding my knees. On February 6th, 2009, I will find out whether I need surgery or not.

Next week, I will type my year in review blog. I hope you all enjoy it. As of now, I don't have any plans for New Year's eve, which isn't surprising. I've only ever gone out for New Year's on one occasion, and that was 3 years ago, when I went to Johnny Power's house for a party with guys on the Jr. Boys basketball team from my high school, TH&VS.
